did.abstract: The papers of Rudy Serra are concentrated on his involvement and interest in the revision of city ordinances in Ferndale and Ypsilanti, Michigan, widening the scope of civil rights protection to include sexual orientation. The collection includes his writings in support of ordinance revision, an article he wrote on sexual orientation and Michigan law, as well as correspondence related to, and press coverage of, the revision process.

bioghist.p: Rudolph A. Serra earned his master's degree at Central Michigan University and his JD at Wayne State University. He served as a research attorney for the Michigan Court of Appeals, was a Ferndale School Board member and Oakland County Commissioner. He was president of the Stonewall Bar Association which assists legal professionals with an interest in sexual orientation issues and the law as it relates to gay, lesbian and bisexual people. Serra served as an attorney, counselor, and social worker through his firm Rudolph A. Serra, P.C., specializing in criminal defense, civil rights, health law, mental health, and consumer litigation. Serra was also a licensed social worker with guardian ad litem and other litigation-support experience. Serra served as a Michigan Democratic Party Officer at Large, chair of the MDP's Gay/Lesbian Caucus and co-chair of the MDP's Justice Caucus. Serra was an alternate delegate to the 2000 Democratic National Convention.
Rudy Serra was appointed as Judge of the 36th District Court in Detroit in 2004 by Governor Granholm.

scopecontent.p: The collection is comprised of four series: Ferndale Civil Rights Ordinance Revision; Ypsilanti Campaign for Equality; Other Litigation; Topical Files; and Writings.

The Ferndale Civil Rights Ordinance Revision series includes Judge Serra's writings about the ordinance, notably an article for the Michigan State Bar entitled "Sexual Orientation and Michigan Law." Other files include correspondence about the ordinance revisions, along with copies of the proposed ordinance revisions. Clippings from local newspapers covering the story are combined with miscellaneous records. A videotape of a Ferndale City Council meeting in 1991 features Serra's appearance as well as other public statements both for and against revisions.

note.p: (The first five minutes of tape are of a TV movie, Council coverage begins after 5 minutes, Mr. Serra appears for three minutes at approximately 30 minutes into the tape, coverage continues with further discussion of proposed amendments)

scopecontent.p: The Ypsilanti Campaign for Equality series contains copies of court documents pertaining to a ballot proposal that, if passed, would have nullified certain Ypsilanti city ordinances. These ordinances were originally enacted to protect the civil rights of gays and lesbians in Ypsilanti. The ballot proposal was defeated in the election of November 2002.
